The Setting of the Letters
     ANYONE WHO HAS DEALT WITH STROKE VICTIMS CAN IDENTIFY WITH ELLEN WHITE WHEN SHE WROTE, "I have not lost my love for my husband, but I cannot explain things."--Letter 67, 1876. A WEEK EARLIER SHE HAD WRITTEN, "I can but dread the liability of James' changeable moods."
265
--Letter 64, 1876. THE CHANGE IN PERSONALITY EXHIBITED BY JAMES WHITE IN THE YEARS AFTER 1865, DURING WHICH HE EXPERIENCED SEVERAL STROKES, WAS VERY DIFFICULT FOR HIS WIFE AND ASSOCIATES TO UNDERSTAND.
